description: pen and brown ink on laid paper

value: he says he cannot give life, & he will / not take it away, & at the same time / that he give[i] inflicts a longer punishment / than death on the the[ii] offender the obliges / him by a life of hard labour to make / some reparation for the injuries committed / & gives the unhappy Creature an opportunity / by continuing his life of making a prepara- / -ation for a better state, yet by this means / of punishment vice is so far terrified / that you may walk thro' the towns or roads / of / this prince's dominions in the middle / of the night with a purse of money in / your hand exposed to view in the most perfect safety & the civility of the people / equals thier[sic] honesty, for a quarrel is very / rarely heard of amongst them & blows they / are utter strangers to; many are the public / Schools established by this prince, his libera- / -lity has provided an Hospital sufficient / to contain all the poor in the City afflicted / with the most loathsome distempers so / that no such objects are seen about the / City & it may naturally be supposed such
[i]preceding word crossed through in brown ink; [ii] preceding word crossed through in brown ink

a Prince would be careful of the honor of his / maker he has taken care to have Sunday / observed with becoming Sanctity which before his time was very little noticed, one instance / of the good government of this City ought / to be mentioned, if a person known to be / a theif or otherwise noxious, to society comes / into Florence, the Country Constables or Sbirri / give notice to the Officers of the City, who imme- / -diately order the person either to return to the / place from whence he came or go to prison / the offender knowing he cannot escape the / vigilence of the civil policy, if he thinks / he cannot be safe in the place he came from whence he came[i] / voluntarily & unaccompanied by any one, goes / to prison in the City, thus neither Thieves / or Prostitutes are to be found here; even in / carnival time when the greatest concourses / are collected, disguised, & mostly unknown / all the amusements are harmless & no mis- / -chief is done, the Duke & Duchess & their family unite in these innocent amusement / & no doubt by their presence & example / contributed to the regularity with with[ii] which
[i] preceding three words appear above the line; [ii] preceding word crossed through in brown ink
Description of the acts of Duke Peter Leopold: on crime and charitable acts in the city of Florence
